channel.title: RSS Aggregator Feed
channel.description: An aggregated feed of Technology-related news

item.title: Napster Is Now a Slop Farm for AI Music
item.description: Now that's what I call slop! Vol. 2.

item.title: ‘Uncanny Valley’: Minneapolis Misinformation, TikTok’s New Owners, and Moltbot Hype
item.description: On this episode of Uncanny Valley, we dive into the news that's held our attention this week: ICE activity as it's been unfolding in Minnesota.

item.title: It’s a new heyday for gas thanks to data centers
item.description: The US is now leading a global surge in new gas power plants being built in large part to satisfy growing energy demand for data centers. And more gas means more planet-heating pollution. Gas-fired power generation in development globally rose by 31 percent in 2025. Almost a quarter of that added capacity is slated for […]

item.title: Amazon is reportedly in talks to invest $50 billion in OpenAI
item.description: If a deal materializes, it would mean Amazon is backing competing startups in the race for AI supremacy.

item.title: Bring the beach to work: I found 34 ocean-inspired upgrades that turn your home office into a seaside sanctuary
item.description: Beautiful office decor for beach-lovers.

item.title: What Is the Future of ‘Dragon Ball’ Without Akira Toriyama?
item.description: Although the recently announced 'Dragon Ball Super: Galactic Patrol' is poised to adapt one of Goku's best arcs, 'Dragon Ball' without Akira Toriyama is gonna be weird to witness.

item.title: 130-inch TVs vs the projector: 2026's giant TV launches point to a new living-room battle
item.description: Choosing between a giant TV and a home theater projector is about to get a lot harder…

item.title: Mercedes-Benz Says the 2027 S-Class Gives Passengers a Better Ride Through AI
item.description: Updates to the vehicle of the financial district include things you can feel, including heated seat belts.

item.title: Apple just had a record-breaking iPhone quarter
item.description: Apple says the iPhone had its "best-ever" quarter, with revenue hitting more than $85.3 billion over the past few months. The company announced the news as part of its Q1 2026 earnings report, which also revealed record-breaking revenue of $143.8 billion, up 16 percent when compared to the same time last year. "The demand for […]

item.title: Medium gives employees Friday off to participate in national strike protesting ICE
item.description: Activists behind the general strike are calling for "no work, no school, and no shopping" amid a push to defund ICE, which has escalated raids in U.S. cities, killing several people, including two U.S. citizens earlier this month in Minneapolis.

item.title: Next-Generation Weather Satellite Captures Earth’s Atmospheric Chaos in Striking Detail
item.description: The first images from the European Space Agency’s MTG-S satellite offer an early look at how the mission will improve weather forecasting across Europe and Northern Africa.

item.title: Micron looks to help ease global chip crisis - new $24 billion Singapore facility should boost NAND supply worldwide, but will it be enough?
item.description: Micron’s $24 billion Singapore expansion aims to boost NAND supply, though long lead times will limit near-term impact on shortages.

item.title: A Waymo Robotaxi Hit a Kid by a School
item.description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened an investigation into the incident.

item.title: Microsoft won’t stop buying AI chips from Nvidia, AMD, even after launching its own, Nadella says
item.description: Microsoft says its own chip leapfrogs those made by other cloud providers like Amazon and Google. But it needs more.

item.title: Apple Drops $2 Billion on Israeli AI Facial Tracking Company
item.description: Tim Cook is having a week.

item.title: Elon Musk’s SpaceX and xAI are reportedly holding merger talks
item.description: Two Elon Musk companies are reportedly planning to merge. On Thursday, Reuters reported that SpaceX and xAI are holding merger talks ahead of a planned IPO. Part of their plan is to launch AI data centers into space (but unfortunately, only as far as Earth's orbit).Last week, it was reported that Musk planned to take SpaceX public despite having once said it wouldn’t happen until the company had a presence on Mars. Now, the IPO could happen as early as this year. Shares of xAI would reportedly be exchanged for shares in SpaceX under the merger. Reuters reports that two entities were set up in ...

item.title: Whoa, Why Has This Frozen Lake Turned Green?
item.description: Scientists say it's a rare natural phenomenon driven by pollution and—yep—climate change.

item.title: The weirdest headphones at CES will launch on Kickstarter next month
item.description: There's never a shortage of weird tech debuting at CES every year. A new company called Tomorrow Doesn't Matter, or TDM, announced a peculiar pair of headphones at the show earlier this month with a feature no one has tried before. The Neo headphones can be rolled up like a hedgehog which turns them into […]

item.title: Amazon Digs Deeper Into the Comics Shelf With a ‘Sex Criminals’ Show
item.description: Prime Video's next comic target is Matt Fraction and Chip Zdarsky's supernaturally weird love story.

item.title: Appels illimités et 1 Go chez Free : le forfait 2 € sort de la préhistoire
item.description: L'opérateur historique du "zéro euro" vient de gonfler son petit forfait sans en toucher le prix. Finies les 2 heures d'appels chronométrées, place à l'illimité et à 1 Go de données.

item.title: Publishers are blocking the Internet Archive for fear AI scrapers can use it as a workaround
item.description: The Internet Archive has often been a valuable resource for journalists, from it's finding records of deleted tweets or providing academic texts for background research. However, the advent of AI has created a new tension between the parties. A few major publications have begun blocking the nonprofit digital library's access to their content based on concerns that AI companies' bots are using the Internet Archive's collections to indirectly scrape their articles."A lot of these AI businesses are looking for readily available, structured databases of content," Robert Hahn, head of business affa...
